Hmm, I may have misinterpreted the policy. I was under the impression that as long as the nose and mouth were covered, it was acceptable. Can you confirm that's not the case?

That's correct. I've consulted the manual, and our policy clearly states that the material must be non-porous or have a filtration efficiency that meets our standards. I also informed the captain of the situation.
I appreciate you bringing this to my attention. I'll make sure to review our procedures to avoid any confusion in the future.
No problem. I approached the passenger and showed them the relevant section of the manual. They initially protested but eventually agreed to exchange the mesh mask for a company-provided one.
Great job resolving the issue. For future reference, would you be willing to provide a note or an update to our team about this situation so we can be more aware of the specific requirements?

Absolutely. I'll make sure to document this in our internal communication channels and provide a reference to the manual for similar situations. The issue is now resolved, and the passenger is wearing a compliant mask.
Thank you for your diligence and for keeping me informed. I appreciate your commitment to upholding our airline's policies and ensuring passenger safety.
Good morning, everyone. Just a heads up, we're expecting a smooth flight today. Lead Flight Attendant, how's the cabin looking?

Good morning, Captain. The cabin is secure, and passengers are settling in. However, I did want to touch base with you about the mask policy on the flight deck. I noticed you're having some trouble wearing your mask while operating the aircraft.

Well, I was thinking of offering you an N95 mask for extra protection. We have some on board, and it might make it easier for you to breathe and perform your duties.

Okay, no problem. However, I do want to mention that one of our flight attendants is a bit concerned about the mask policy on the flight deck. She's been wearing a single-layer cloth mask, and I'm not sure if that's in line with company policy.
What's the issue with her mask?
She's adamant that her cloth mask is sufficient, but I'm worried it may not provide the level of protection we need. I've offered her an N95 mask, but she's refused.
Excuse me, Lead Flight Attendant, but I don't see why I need to wear a different mask. My cloth mask is perfectly fine.
I understand your perspective, but company policy recommends wearing a medical-grade mask or N95 for crew members on duty. It's not about being overly cautious; it's about ensuring everyone's safety.
But I've been wearing this mask the entire time, and nothing's changed. Why are we suddenly making a big deal about it now?

Hi, [Flight Attendant's Name], can I have a word with you for a minute?

I just received a report from a passenger about a situation that occurred during takeoff. Apparently, a father and a small boy were in the lavatory, and there was a concern about the sterile cockpit rules being compromised. I'd like to get to the bottom of what happened.

I think I know what you're referring to, Captain. I made an interphone call to [Crew Member's Name] during takeoff, but I didn't think it was necessary to notify the cockpit. I was trying to get someone to check on the situation in the lavatory.

I understand your intention, but that's exactly the problem. During critical phases of flight, like takeoff, we need to minimize distractions and maintain sterile cockpit procedures. If there's a safety concern, it's crucial that we get informed immediately. Can you tell me more about what happened?

Well, Captain, I did get a bit busy with the passenger load and the delays we experienced. We had issues with the aircraft availability and weather reroutes, and I think I might have dropped the ball on communicating with the cockpit.

Delays can be challenging, I agree. However, it's precisely during those times that we need to be extra vigilant. As you know, we came close to missing our departure time, and I have safety concerns about not being informed about the lavatory situation during takeoff. If there was an issue that required an aborted takeoff, every second counts.
I understand your concerns, Captain. It was an oversight on my part. I'll make sure to be more diligent in the future, especially with our diverse crew and the importance of clear communication.

I appreciate your willingness to learn from this, [Flight Attendant's Name]. It's essential that we work together to ensure passenger safety. Let's review our communication protocols and make sure everyone is on the same page. I'd like to discuss this further in our debriefing after the next flight.

Captain, I need to inform you of a situation on board. We have a passenger who has a highly contagious disease. It's not airborne, but it can be transmitted through contact. She's requested that her seat be cleaned with Clorox after deplaning.

Captain, we've got a bit of a situation in the galley. The oven is smoking, and I think it's because the dinner rolls are burning.
(alarmed) What? Get the passengers away from the galley, and let's assess the situation.
(calmly) Captain, I think we can handle this. It's just a minor issue. We can continue on to our destination.
(firmly) No, we're not taking any chances. We're diverting to ZZZ2 for an overweight inspection. I don't want to risk anything.
(surprised) But, Captain, I think we can...
(interrupting) No, First Officer. I've made my decision. Let's get the passengers off the aircraft and sort this out.
(concerned) Okay, Captain. We'll get the
Hi, I'm from maintenance. We had a 'Warn Elec' message on this aircraft and we're trying to troubleshoot the issue. Can you tell me if you've experienced anything unusual?
No, we haven't had any issues reported to us. What's the nature of the 'Warn Elec' message?
It's indicating a potential electrical issue. We're going to try to reset some circuit breakers to see if that resolves the problem.
Okay, that's good to know. Do you need us to do anything to facilitate your work?
Actually, we're waiting for a jetway operator to arrive so we can safely access the aircraft. Can you let the captain know that we're still waiting on that?
I'll let him know. But are you sure it's safe to enter the aircraft without a jetway operator? We don't want anyone to get hurt.
I agree, but we're trying to get this issue resolved quickly. I'll make sure to follow all safety protocols. (pauses) Actually, I think we'll go ahead and enter through the hatch.
(cautiously) Okay... well, please be careful. (steps back, then accidentally steps through the hatch) Oh no!
(simultaneously entering the aircraft) Whoa! Be careful!
(after the accident) I'm so sorry, I didn't mean for that to happen. Are you okay?
(assessing injuries) No, I don't think so... I think I need some medical attention.
I'll call for medical help right away. And I need to report this incident to my team. This wasn't supposed to happen.
(gratefully) Thank you... I appreciate your concern.
Captain, we have a request from a mother who's asking if her toddler can use the restroom before departure. She's concerned about having to hold it during the flight.
Ah, okay. That's understandable. Yes, let her use the lavatory. Give them about 2-3 minutes.
Will do, Captain. I'll let them know.
(to the First Officer) Alright, let's get ready for pushback.
(reminding the Captain) Captain, just a reminder that we still have passengers in the lavatory.
(over the intercom) Alright, let's go. We're cleared for departure.
(concerned) Captain, I understand, but we still have passengers in the lavatory.
(firmly) I know, let's go.
(at 10,000 feet) Captain, I've escorted the gentleman and toddler back to their seats. They're safely stowed.
(over the intercom) Sorry about that. I wasn't aware we were moving up in the departure order. I didn't mean to cause any issues.
No worries, Captain. I ensured the passengers' safety during the process. I just wanted to make sure you were aware of the situation.
(apologetically) I appreciate that. Sorry again for the oversight. Let's make sure to communicate better next time.
Absolutely, Captain. Let's focus on providing a safe and comfortable flight for our passengers.
Captain, I need to discuss a concern I have with one of our passengers. The lady in 1A, she's a premium frequent flyer, and I've had some issues with her not complying with safety regulations.
What's the situation, [Flight Attendant's name]?

I asked her to end her phone call and switch to airplane mode as we were closing the cabin door, but she's refused to do so. Despite my repeated requests, she's continued using her phone and it's still connected to service.
I see. How have you handled the situation so far?

Honestly, Captain, I've been hesitant to take further action. I know she's a high-value customer and I didn't want to escalate the situation. But at the same time, I'm concerned about the safety implications if she's not willing to follow basic safety rules.
I understand your concerns. However, we need to ensure that all passengers comply with safety regulations. Have you informed her of the specific rules and the reasons behind them?
Yes, Captain. I've explained to her that we need her phone to be in airplane mode for the safety of everyone on board, but she's just ignored me.
Okay, let's work together to resolve this. Have you considered speaking with her again and explaining the situation in a clear and firm but polite manner?
I was thinking of doing that, but I was worried about potential repercussions from the company. You know how it is with premium passengers.

I understand your concerns, but safety is our top priority. We need to ensure that all passengers comply with regulations. Let's go over to her together and address the issue. I'll support you in enforcing compliance.
Thank you, Captain. I appreciate your support.
That's what I'm here for. Let's go take care of this and make sure everyone on board is safe.
Hey, Mike. I need to talk to you about something that happened on our flight yesterday.
What's up, Sam? Everything okay?
Yeah, everything's fine. But I had a bit of a situation with a passenger in premium economy. She was using her electronic device in what looked like prohibited mode.
Okay, which seat was she in?
1C. Anyway, I went over to remind her to switch it to airplane mode, and she kind of gave me a smug look. I asked her politely to switch it, but she just smiled and kept using it.
That sounds frustrating. Did you ask her again?
Yeah, I did. I went back to her a few minutes later and asked her to switch it again. But she just shook her head and kept on using it. It was like she thought she was above the rules.
That attitude can be tough to deal with. Did you consider reporting it to the captain?

Honestly, Mike, I didn't. I didn't feel like it was worth it. I know the company has procedures in place for situations like this, but I wasn't sure if they'd back me up. I've heard cases where crew members have reported incidents like this and haven't gotten much support.
That's a fair point. It can be a challenge to know when to escalate and when not to. But it's good that you documented it in your log, right?
Yeah, I did. Just in case. But I'm not sure what else I could have done in that situation. It felt like she was intentionally being non-compliant.
Yeah, those can be tough situations. Maybe we can touch base with the inflight team and see if they've had any similar incidents. Sometimes it's helpful to get their perspective on how to handle it.
That's a great idea. Thanks, Mike. I just wanted to run it by you and get your thoughts.
Good morning, Flight 121. This is Dispatch. We're expecting some significant delays due to weather and air traffic control issues. Can you confirm your estimated departure time?
Good morning, Dispatch. This is Flight 121. We're currently on the gate, but we're running about 30 minutes behind schedule. What's the latest on the weather?

Ah, yeah. The weather is looking pretty rough. We've got a storm system moving in, and we're expecting some turbulence. I'm going to go ahead and adjust your routing to avoid the worst of it. Can you expect a revised flight plan shortly?
Roger that, Dispatch. What's the plan for fuel? We're already running a bit low due to the delay.

Okay, let me check on that. (pause) Alright, I'm showing you have enough fuel to make it to your destination, but we're going to need to keep a close eye on it. I'm going to assign you an additional fuel stop.
Okay, that sounds good. What's the status on our flight attendants? We're getting some reports of a medical emergency on board.
(urgently) Okay, Flight 121, we need to move quickly on this. Can you give me more information on the medical emergency?
(concerned) Yeah, we've got a passenger who's experiencing severe chest pain. We're trying to get the flight attendant to patch in on the radio, but we're not getting any response.

(calmly) Okay, stay calm. I'm going to try to get someone to assist you. (pause) Chief in training, Bravo-12, can you assist the domestic dispatcher on Flight 121? We've got a medical emergency on board.
(relieved) Ah, thank you, Dispatch. We're going to try to get the passenger stabilized until help arrives.
(firmly) Okay, good. I'm going to get someone on the radio to walk you through the protocol. Just hang tight.
Alright, we're about to start our descent and get ready for landing. Let's review the cabin.
Yes, Captain. We've got everything secure back here.
Great. I want to discuss the takeoff procedure with you. I realize I didn't give the standard "prepare for departure" command.
That's correct, Captain. We were in the galley when we heard the chime and assumed it was a call light.
I see. And what was your position during takeoff?
We were standing in the galley, holding the carts in place. They weren't secured, so we had to make sure they didn't move.
I understand. That's not an ideal situation. We need to ensure that you're properly positioned for takeoff in case of an emergency.
Agreed, Captain. It was a bit chaotic. We're lucky everything went smoothly.

I concur. To prevent this from happening again, I will make sure to consistently issue the "prepare for departure" command. Can you confirm that you'll be in your designated seats with seatbelts fastened once you hear that command?
Absolutely, Captain. We'll make sure to follow procedure from now on. And I appreciate your emphasis on safety.
Safety is our top priority. Let's review the procedures one more time to ensure we're all on the same page.
Sounds good, Captain. I'll make sure to pass it on to the rest of the crew as well.

Hi Dispatch, this is Flight Attendant XXX on Flight 123 to ZZZ. I'm calling to clarify my crew assignment. I was told by the gate agent that I was boarding as the incoming crew, but I'm showing a different trip on the crew portal.
Good morning, Flight Attendant XXX. Can you confirm your employee ID and the trip number you're showing on the portal?
My ID is 12345, and I'm showing Trip 456, but I was told I'd be relieving the incoming crew. I'm getting a bit confused.

Okay, let me check on that. (pause) I apologize for the confusion. It looks like there was a miscommunication on our end. You are indeed scheduled for Trip 456, but we had a crew scheduling issue that caused the delay. The incoming crew is running behind, and we asked the gate agent to board you early.
That makes sense now. But I did notice my phone rang during taxi, and I know I shouldn't have answered it. I realize that was a mistake on my part.

(firmly) Flight Attendant XXX, I appreciate your honesty. However, I need to remind you that using electronic devices during critical flight phases is a serious policy violation. I'm sure you recall the training on this.
Absolutely, Dispatch. I know better than to use my phone during taxi. It was a lapse in judgment, and I accept responsibility.

(calmly) Alright, we'll need to document this incident, and you'll receive additional training on communication protocols and electronic device usage. Let's focus on getting you through the rest of your trip safely, and we'll discuss the details further when you return to base.
Understood, Dispatch. Thank you for your understanding. I'll make sure to follow procedure going forward.
Captain, I've just completed my compliance check in first class, and I noticed the cabin door is still open. I wanted to bring this to your attention immediately.
Ah, thank you for letting me know. I'll get that taken care of. Can you confirm the status of the cabin with your colleagues?
I've already spoken with one of my colleagues, but I'm not sure if they've checked with everyone. I just wanted to make sure you were aware before we proceed.
Alright, I'll check with the other flight attendants. (pause) Okay, I've just received confirmation from one of the flight attendants that the cabin is secure.
I apologize, Captain, but I haven't received confirmation from my colleague, and I can see the door is still open. I'm concerned we shouldn't proceed with pushback.
I've been informed it's secure, but I'll double-check. (pause) Alright, let's get that door closed and then we can proceed.
Captain, I wanted to discuss the incident that occurred during pushback. I had informed you the cabin door was open, but we still proceeded. I believe this was a serious safety and security risk.
I agree, and I apologize for the mistake. We'll need to review this incident and ensure it doesn't happen again. Can you provide more details on what happened from your perspective?

From what I understand, another flight attendant reported the cabin as secure, but it clearly wasn't. I think this highlights a need for improved communication and training on our safety protocols to prevent such incidents in the future.

I couldn't agree more. We'll make sure to review our procedures and provide additional training to ensure everyone is on the same page. Your diligence in reporting the issue likely prevented a more serious incident. Thank you for your professionalism.
Thank you, Captain. I just want to ensure we're always following the regulations and keeping our passengers and crew safe.
Absolutely, that's our top priority. I'll make sure to document this incident and we'll discuss it further with the crew and management.

Hi, Rachel. I need to discuss something with you regarding our boarding process. I noticed a passenger seated in the overwing exit row who I'm concerned may not be able to perform the necessary tasks in an emergency.
What's the situation? Did you get a chance to assess them during boarding?

Honestly, I was distracted and didn't get a good look until after we departed. But from what I can see, they're significantly smaller than I expected. I'm talking around 42 inches tall and 80-90 pounds.
That's concerning. Did you speak with them or get a chance to evaluate their mobility?

Not yet, but I'm worried that they might not be able to open the exit door or assist others in an emergency. I'm hesitant to approach the situation because I don't want to come across as discriminatory.

I understand your concern. We had another crew member confirm their ability to assist during boarding, but it's clear we need to take a closer look. We can't afford to have a situation where someone is unable to perform the required tasks.
Exactly! And with the current climate, I'm worried that if we do ask them to move, it could be perceived as discriminatory and end up in the media.

That's a valid concern. We need to propose a solution to ensure we're not putting passengers in a situation where they can't assist. Perhaps we can add a step to our boarding process to evaluate passengers' abilities before assigning exit row seating.

That's a great idea. If we can assess their ability to assist during boarding, we can avoid this situation altogether. I'll make a note to discuss this with the captain and see if we can implement a change for future flights.

Sounds like a plan. Let's also make sure to document this incident and share it with our team to raise awareness about the importance of evaluating passengers' abilities before assigning exit row seating.
Captain, I need to speak with you about a situation that occurred on our flight today. We had a passenger in first class who was causing some issues.
What's going on? Was it a medical emergency or a behavioral issue?

It was a behavioral issue. I found three smokeless cigarette butts near his seat in the first-class cabin. When we confronted him about it on deplaning, he became very aggressive and used explicit language.
I see. Did you address the issue with him during the flight?

Yes, he was confrontational throughout the flight, complaining about our alcohol service and using offensive language. He refused to follow crew instructions to remain seated and made some very inappropriate comments.
That sounds like a difficult passenger. Did you document his behavior?
Yes, I did. I highlighted his defiance and disregard for crew responsibilities. I'm concerned that he may try to take legal action against us or try to get banned from the airline.
Okay, let's take a look at the documentation. What was his response when you confronted him about the cigarette butts?

He claimed that the butts were in his pocket and that he had already filed a negative review about our service. He also falsely accused us of misconduct, saying that we were unfairly targeting him and his family. We did offer extra forms for his elderly grandparents, but it was completely above board.
I see. We'll need to review the CCTV footage and your documentation. Have you spoken with the other crew members about the incident?
Yes, I've spoken with the other flight attendant who was working with me. We're both in agreement that the passenger's behavior was unacceptable and created a hostile environment for us.

Okay, let's get to the bottom of this. I'll talk to our operations team about potentially banning him from future flights. You and your colleague did a great job managing the situation, but I want to make sure we're covering all our bases.
Thank you, Captain. I appreciate your support.
Of course. Let's keep a close eye on this and make sure we're documenting everything.
Hey, Rachel, I wanted to touch base with you about what happened on our last flight. I know we had a bit of a miscommunication about the First Officer's status as an FFDO.
Oh, yeah? What happened? I thought we had covered that before takeoff.

I had asked John to pass on the information to the rest of the crew after the door closed, but I guess it got lost in the shuffle during the pre-takeoff taxi process. We were all busy making sure passengers were seated and belted in, and it just didn't happen.

I can see how that would get missed. It was a bit chaotic out there. But we need to make sure we're all on the same page, especially when it comes to something like that. Have you thought of any ways we can improve our communication on this in the future?

Actually, I was thinking that maybe we could implement a system in our computer to denote FFDOs with a triangle symbol or something. That way, it would be right there in front of us during boarding and pre-takeoff procedures. We could also make sure to add it to our pre-flight briefing checklist.

That's not a bad idea. It would definitely help us stay on top of that information, even when things get busy. And we could also make sure to double-check with the cockpit crew before takeoff to confirm their status. Let's run it by the captain and see what he thinks.

Sounds good to me. I'll make a note to bring it up at our next crew meeting and see if we can get something implemented. Thanks for owning up to it and suggesting a solution – it's all about improving our processes and keeping everyone safe.

Captain, I need to bring to your attention a concern I have about an item in the overhead bin. A passenger identified it as a drum set with a lithium battery. It's a large, hard-covered box and I'm worried about its safety.
What's the issue with it?
For one, it's huge. It won't even fit into a battery containment bag. And with lithium batteries on board, especially for a five-hour overwater flight, I'm not comfortable with it being up there.
I see. Let me talk to the CSR and see what they have to say about it.
I've already spoken with them, sir. They weren't able to provide much information. I was hoping we could get some clarification on whether this item was properly approved to be on board.
Okay, I'll see what I can find out. But in the meantime, we do have other lithium battery-powered devices on board, like cell phones and laptops. What's the difference here?

Those are small, contained devices that are designed for everyday use. This is a large, hard-covered box with a lithium battery. I just don't think it's comparable. And I think we should be taking a closer look at this before we continue with the flight.
I understand your concerns, but I think it's acceptable. The passenger seems to know what they're doing with it.

But have we done our due diligence to ensure it's safe? I think we need to have a more thorough process in place for checking items like this before departure. This incident has raised some red flags for me about our procedures for handling lithium batteries.
I hear you. Let's review our procedures and see if there's anything we can do to improve them. In the meantime, I'll talk to the passenger and make sure they're aware of the procedures and protocols.
Thank you, Captain. I appreciate your attention to this matter. I just want to make sure we're doing everything we can to ensure the safety of our passengers and crew.
Hi, I'm concerned about the two carrier boxes filled with dry ice that are sitting in front of the boarding door. Can you please move them to a safe location?
I'm not going to move them. The chiller isn't working, so we had to leave them here.
I wasn't informed that the chiller was inoperative. Can you please find another place to put them? They're a tripping hazard for our passengers.
No, you need to take them on board. That's not my problem.
I understand that it's not your problem, but it's a safety issue for us. The boxes are too heavy for me to lift safely. Can you please help me find a solution?
Like I said, you need to take them. I'm not going to touch them.
(calling for assistance) Hi, In-Flight Supervisor, can you please come over here and help me with this issue?
The catering representative left two heavy boxes of dry ice in front of the boarding door and refuses to move them. They're a tripping hazard.
I tried to explain that they're too heavy for me to lift safely. Can you please help me find a solution?
(into radio) Captain, I need your assistance. We have a situation with catering leaving two heavy boxes of dry ice in front of the boarding door...
(over radio) I've been informed that chiller number 7 in the aft galley is having an issue. I'll send someone to help.
(to Catering Representative) I'm going to have to take these boxes on board myself to avoid further delay.
Fine, do what you want.
(sighs) Alright, I'll take them. (lifts boxes and carries them onto the aircraft)
(to herself) Well, that was resolved, but a bit unprofessionally handled, if you ask me.
Good morning, this is Captain. We've started the first engine and we're showing a warning indication that the forward door is ajar. Can you please check the door and make sure it's secure?
Roger that, Captain. I'll check the door. (pause) Okay, I'm checking... and it looks like the door is not fully closed. I'm going to try to close it now.
Alright, can you try to close it and then let me know if the warning clears? And can you also try to 'recycle' the door to make sure everything is functioning properly?
Recycle the door? You mean just close it again and make sure it's latched?
No, I think what the Captain means is to close the door, then open it again, and then close it once more to reset the system.
Okay, got it. (pause) I'm going to do that now. (pause) Wait, what's happening? The slide is deploying!
What's going on? Did you release the door handle?
No, I didn't touch the handle! I was just trying to close the door again. I thought I was supposed to recycle it like you said.
Alright, let's stay calm. We've got an inadvertent slide deployment. Can you please make sure everyone is safe and accounted for?
Everyone's okay, Captain. No injuries. But I think there might have been a miscommunication about what 'recycle' means.
Agreed. We'll need to review this incident and make sure we're all on the same page. Let's get the passengers deplaned and then we'll do a thorough debrief.
Hey, have you guys noticed that passenger in 17C? He seems a bit out of it.
You mean the one who smells like weed? Yeah, I caught that too. I also noticed his eyes are pretty glossy and he's being really loud.
I agree, I was thinking the same thing. I approached him and asked if he was okay, and he admitted to smoking marijuana throughout the day.
That's concerning. Did he seem receptive to moving to a different seat, like we discussed?
Actually, I asked him to move to the mid to aft cabin, but he refused. I'm getting a bit worried about his condition, especially since he's sitting by an overwing exit.
I share your concern. If he's impaired, it could be a safety issue in an emergency. We should discuss this with the rest of the crew and see what we can do.
I already spoke with the captain, but I didn't get a verbal response. I'm not sure if they're taking it seriously.
A deemed him acceptable, but I don't agree. With his behavior and the fact that he's clearly under the influence, I think we should take action.

I'm with you on that. The manual says we need to be concerned about intoxicated passengers, but it doesn't specifically mention marijuana. Does that make a difference, since it's legal in some states?

That's a good point, but I still think we need to prioritize safety here. We can't have someone who's potentially impaired sitting in a critical seat. Let's try to get a better handle on this and figure out our next steps.
Agreed. We should also document this in the incident report and maybe suggest an update to the manual to include clarification on substances like marijuana.
Captain, we have a situation on board. One of our passengers has been vaping marijuana in the aft lavatory. We noticed a strong smell when he exited and observed smoke inside the lavatory.
What's the passenger's behavior like? Is he cooperative?
He's acting paranoid, sir. I'm not sure if he's going to be a problem.
Okay, let's get him isolated and prepare for landing. I'll make an announcement to the passengers and get the authorities on standby. Can you and the other attendants keep an eye on him?
Already on it, Captain. We'll keep him under surveillance until we land.
Great. Let's get the police waiting at the gate. I'll handle the announcement and get the plane on the ground as soon as possible.
Sounds good, Captain. We're preparing for landing.
(over the intercom) Ladies and gentlemen, we'll be landing shortly. Please make sure your seatbelts are securely fastened.
(to the passenger) Sir, we need to speak with you. Can you please come with me?
What's going on?
We need to discuss a matter with you. Please, just come with me.
(at the gate) Can you tell me what happened?
We observed smoke in the aft lavatory and a strong smell of marijuana. The passenger was vaping marijuana on board.
And did he cooperate with you?
Initially, no. He denied any wrongdoing.
And what about this vape pen we found on him?
That's the one we found in his possession. I'm told it tested positive for THC.
(to the passenger) Sir, we know you were vaping marijuana on the flight. You might as well tell us the truth.
(defeated) I...I smoked in the cabin and lavatory. I didn't mean to cause any trouble.
You're going to have to come with us, sir.
I'm glad that's over. I'm experiencing some throat irritation and a headache.
That's likely from the THC exposure. You should get checked out.
Will do. Thanks for handling this. We'll need to file a report.
Of course. We'll take it from here.

Hi, I'm calling from Flight 121. We have a concern about a piece of equipment that was brought on board by a passenger. It appears to be a battery-powered Segway, but I'm not sure if it's considered a hoverboard or not.
Okay, let me check on that. Can you give me the passenger's name or the bag tag number?

Unfortunately, I don't have that information. The passenger boarded with it, and I'm not sure if it's been checked or not. I'm concerned about the type of battery used in the device. Can you tell me if it's a lithium-ion or a different type?
Hold on... (pause) Okay, I've checked with our team. The TSA has approved the device, and it's been tagged as checked baggage.
That's helpful, but I still don't know what type of battery is used in the device. That's my main concern. Can you find out for me?
(pause) I'm not sure if I can get that specific information. It's been cleared by TSA, so... (trails off)

I understand that, but as a crew, we need to ensure that it's safe to transport. I've checked our manual, and I couldn't find any specific information about this type of device. Can you confirm if it's considered a hazardous material or not?
(pause) Like I said, it's been cleared by TSA. I'm sure it's fine.
I appreciate your help, but I still have concerns. Can you please escalate this to your supervisor or someone who can provide more information?
(pause) Okay, I'll make a note of it. But the device is already loaded in the cargo hold, so...
I understand. I just want to ensure that we're not violating any safety protocols. Can you please follow up with me on this?
Yeah, I'll make sure someone looks into it. Thanks for bringing this to my attention.
Appreciate it. If I don't hear back, I'll make sure to file an incident report.
Sounds good. Have a safe flight.
Hi, this is Flight 123, we've just had a bit of a situation on the taxiway. Can you please confirm you're the ground personnel handling our communication?
Yes, that's correct. I'm Ground Control. What's the situation with your flight?

We had a taxiway incursion on Taxiway R, crossing Runway 11/29. The Captain received confusing taxi instructions and mistakenly turned onto the taxiway. We're okay, but we'd like to get some clarification on further instructions.
I see. Can you confirm your current location and what you see around you? Are you clear of the runway?
Yes, we're clear of the runway. We've set the brakes and are waiting for further instructions. The Captain's got the frequencies straightened out with the crew now.
Okay, Flight 123. I've got the information here. Can you confirm you're on the correct frequency with me now?
Yes, that's correct. We're on the ground frequency.
Alright. I'm going to clear you to continue taxiing to the gate. Be advised, we're going to look into improving taxiway signage in that area, especially during winter ops.
Roger that. We'll proceed to the gate with caution. And just to confirm, do you want us to file an ASRS report or is that already being handled?
We'll take care of it on our end, but I appreciate the offer. Just get the passengers safely to their destination and we'll debrief further when you get to the gate.
Will do. Thanks for the understanding. Flight 123, clear to taxi to the gate.
You're welcome, Flight 123. Safe taxiing.
Captain, I wanted to speak with you about the seat belt sign usage on our recent flights. I've noticed that it's been left on for the entire duration of the flight, even during periods of smooth air.
Ah, yeah. I know what you're referring to. We're just trying to err on the side of caution with all the turbulence we've been experiencing lately. Don't want anyone to get caught off guard.

I understand your concerns about turbulence, but leaving the seat belt sign on for 6.5 to 9.5 hours can actually create a safety risk. Passengers start to ignore it, and it becomes a challenge for us to enforce compliance. Not to mention, it's against regulations - FAR 121.311 specifically.
I wasn't aware of that. Our concern is liability, to be honest. If we do encounter severe turbulence and someone's not buckled up... well, you know.

I understand that, but there are guidelines in place for a reason. And it's not just about liability; it's about fostering a safety culture on board. When passengers see the seat belt sign on for hours on end, they start to think it's not a big deal. I observed at least 15 passengers in the aisle during a flight when the seat belt sign was on, and that's just not safe.
I see your point. Maybe we can revisit our procedures for long-range flights. What do you suggest we do differently?

Well, perhaps we could follow the standard operating procedures for seat belt sign usage, and only turn it on when there's actual turbulence or a forecast for turbulence? That way, we're not creating complacency among passengers or flight attendants.
That's a good point. I'll discuss it with the rest of the crew and see what we can do to improve our procedures. Appreciate you bringing this to my attention.
Thank you, Captain. I just want to make sure we're prioritizing safety on board.
Absolutely, we all are. Let's make sure to get it right.

Captain, before we start the briefing, I just wanted to review our cockpit access procedures with you. As you know, our training and manual protocols require us to lock the lavatory doors during cockpit access.
Ah, yeah, I know. Just keep them open, it's fine.
I apologize, Captain, but I'm required to follow our established procedures. Locking the lavatory doors is a security measure to ensure the cockpit remains secure.
Look, I've flown with this crew before, and we've always kept them open. It's not a big deal.

I understand, Captain, but I'd like to respectfully disagree. Our training specifically states that lavatory doors should be locked during cockpit access. If we don't follow this procedure, it could potentially compromise the security of the cockpit.
I'm telling you, it's not necessary. Just keep them open, and let's get moving.
Captain, I'm not comfortable with that. As a flight attendant, it's my responsibility to ensure that our security protocols are followed. I'm going to have to insist that we lock the lavatory doors.
Fine, do what you have to do. But can we please just move on with the briefing?

(pausing, concerned) Captain, I want to make sure we're clear on this. I'm going to document this in my report, and I'll also bring it up with our supervisor after the flight. I think we need to have a discussion about standardizing our procedures.
(sighs) Look, let's just focus on getting the flight done safely, okay? We can discuss it later.

(firmly) Understood, Captain. However, I want to ensure that we're all on the same page regarding our security protocols. I'll make sure to review our procedures with the rest of the crew before we land.
(over interphone) Flight Attendant, this is the captain. We received a report of an incident on board. Can you please provide more information?
(calmly) Okay, let's take a deep breath. Can you please tell me what happened and which attendant is injured?
(concerned) Alright, let's stay calm. Can you confirm if Number 1 is conscious and okay?
(to Number 3 FA) Number 3, I appreciate your concern, but I have Number 2 on the line now. Can you please let me take over the communication?
(to Number 2 FA) Number 2, what's the status of Number 1? Does he need medical assistance?
(to Number 2 FA) Alright, thank you for the update. Please keep an eye on him. We'll prepare for landing. Number 1 wants a supervisor to meet us at ZZZ1, correct?
(to Number 2 FA) Okay, we'll make sure that's arranged. We'll review the incident after landing.
Hi, Captain. I wanted to debrief with you about the incident that occurred during boarding. I feel like things got away from me for a bit.
What's on your mind? You seemed a bit frazzled during boarding.

Well, to be honest, the Gate Agent was being really pushy to close the door, and I got distracted trying to manage the bags and deal with the lavatory usage. I had an elderly passenger five rows back who needed assistance, and I didn't want to leave her stranded.
I see. That can be tough. But what about the exit row passengers? I noticed they weren't briefed until after we started boarding.

Exactly! That's what I'm concerned about. I completely overlooked briefing them during the initial boarding process. It wasn't until I realized the aisle was blocked by a backpack and we were already running behind that I remembered to brief them.
Okay, let's take a step back. What do you think contributed to the oversight? Was it just the distractions, or was there something else at play?

I think it was a combination of things. The Gate Agent's pressure to close the door, the lavatory usage, and managing the bags all took my attention away from the exit row briefing. And to be honest, our boarding process was a bit delayed to begin with.

Alright, well, let's make sure to prioritize those safety protocols, especially the exit row briefing. We can't afford to have those passengers not understand their responsibilities in an emergency. What do you plan to do differently next time?

Absolutely. Next time, I'll make sure to delegate tasks to the other attendants and prioritize that briefing, even if it means politely telling the Gate Agent that we need a bit more time. And I'll make sure to stay focused on the safety protocols, even with all the other distractions.

Sounds like a plan. Let's also make a note to review our boarding procedures and see if there's anything we can do to streamline the process and reduce distractions. Good job recognizing the issue and taking responsibility, by the way.
Good morning, let's go over the events of the final boarding procedures. I understand there was an issue with the entry door being closed by ground personnel without clearance from our team.
That's correct, Captain. I didn't give anyone permission to close the door. I was still on the jetway coordinating with the rest of the crew. I think there was a miscommunication on their part.

I granted clearance, assuming it was one of our team members requesting it. But I have to admit, it was a busy cockpit and I couldn't visually confirm who it was. What's the company's policy on this again?

As per our policy, Captain, the Flight Attendant must authorize the closure of the entry door. It's our responsibility to ensure that all passengers and crew are safely on board before the door is closed.
I see. Well, in hindsight, it's clear that the ground personnel didn't follow procedure. What do you think we can do to prevent this from happening in the future?

I think ground personnel need to be trained to follow proper procedures and wait for our authorization before closing the door. We should also emphasize to pilots the importance of confirming the identity of the person requesting clearance, especially in a busy cockpit.

Agreed. I'll make sure to pass this along to the pilots. And let's make sure to reiterate to our team the importance of clear communication protocols during boarding procedures. We need to work together to ensure everyone's safety.

Absolutely, Captain. I think this incident highlights the need for enhanced training and communication between our teams. Let's make sure to document this incident and provide feedback to the ground personnel and our crew.

Good morning, crew. I've noticed a discrepancy in our Souls On Board count. According to the Weight and Balance report, we have 144 souls on board - 138 passengers, 1 infant, and 5 crew. Can you confirm this count?
Actually, Captain, I have 139 passengers and 1 infant on board. I'm not sure where the extra passenger is.
That's not what the report shows. Can you double-check your count?
I've checked with my colleagues, and we're all in agreement. There are 139 passengers, not 138. And the infant is sitting in a lap, not occupying a seat.
I see. Let's investigate this further. Can you check with the gate agent to see if there's any discrepancy on their end?
I've already spoken with the gate agent, and they're checking on it. Apparently, one of the boarding passes wasn't scanned.
That would explain the discrepancy. Can you get an update from the gate agent on the correct count?
Yes, Captain. The gate agent just confirmed that we have 139 passengers and 1 infant on board. They're sending an updated Takeoff Data version.

Great, thank you. Let's recalculate our Before Push Checklist with the correct numbers. I want to emphasize to everyone that accurate passenger counts are crucial for aircraft weight calculations and emergency response.
Absolutely, Captain. I understand the importance of accurate counts.

It's not just about numbers; it's about ensuring the safety and accurate accounting of lives on board. I've always thought that the FAA should consider requiring a return to physically counting passengers before departure. It's a time-consuming process, I know, but it's essential.
I agree, Captain. It's a good point. We often rely on technology, but sometimes it fails.
Exactly. And in cases like this, it's better to be safe than sorry. Let's make sure to double-check our counts in the future. Alright, let's get back to our pre-departure checks.
Yes, Captain. We'll get started on that.

Captain, we've just had a bit of a situation on our hands. We didn't hear the final descent chime and weren't aware of the impending landing until we saw the street lights outside. We had to rush to secure the cabin and assist passengers.
I apologize to hear that. Can you tell me what happened from your perspective? Did you make the initial descent announcement and start securing the galley as usual?

Yes, we made the initial descent announcement about 20 minutes out and started securing the galley and performing last-minute tasks. One of our attendants collided with the flight deck door and sustained a head injury during the rush to secure the cabin.
I'm sorry to hear that. I did activate the final descent chime, but it appears we had a system malfunction. I'll make sure to note that in the incident report.

Thank you, First Officer. It's just fortunate that everyone is okay. However, I do want to emphasize that a reliable communication system is crucial in ensuring passenger and crew safety during critical phases of flight. This incident could have had more serious consequences if someone had been seriously injured or if we hadn't been able to respond quickly.

I completely agree. I'll file an incident report and we'll review this with maintenance to prevent it from happening again. In the meantime, let's focus on getting our passengers safely on the ground and providing any necessary medical attention to the injured attendant.
Will do, Captain. And thank you for taking this seriously. We'll make sure to debrief further once we've completed the flight.
Hi, I just got back from that morning flight and I had a bit of a situation with a passenger. I wanted to debrief with you about it.
Ah, yeah, I heard there was an issue. What happened?

So, we had a passenger, Passenger X, with a large carry-on bag that didn't fit in the overhead bin. I politely asked him to check it, and he became belligerent, saying I was being rude and yelling at him.

Okay, got it. And what happened when we landed?
As we were disembarking, Passenger X made a comment to me about being intoxicated. I was taken aback, and the captain reported it to the authorities, which led to a police investigation.
That's crazy. How did you handle the investigation?
I cooperated fully, of course. I took a breathalyzer test and provided all the necessary information. Thankfully, the results showed no impairment, and the investigation was closed.
Well, I'm glad that got cleared up. I'm sorry you had to go through that. How are you feeling about it now?

I'm just relieved it's over. I wish Passenger X had understood that I was just doing my job and being professional. I think he misinterpreted my energy and enthusiasm for being intoxicated. It's a shame, because I take pride in providing great customer service.
Absolutely. We'll make sure to document the incident and provide support if you need it. Thanks for sharing what happened.
Captain, I need to bring to your attention that the interphone system is not functioning. According to the aircraft manual, we're not cleared for departure with an inoperative interphone system.
I understand your concern, but we can still operate the flight safely. We can open the flight deck door during takeoff and landing as an alternative protocol.

I understand your concerns, but we can't delay the flight. We have a tight schedule to keep. And besides, opening the flight deck door during takeoff and landing is a standard procedure in this situation.

That sounds great, Captain. I appreciate your willingness to address this and make changes to ensure our safety and well-being. We'll get the reports filled out and make sure FAs B and C get the necessary documentation for their injuries.

Noted, doors clear. I'll just crack open the L1 door now.

Exactly. Fatigue and distractions can definitely play a role in situations like this. Let's make sure to review EICAS messages more thoroughly in the future to prevent this from happening again.
Absolutely, I'll make sure to double-check my procedures and we can discuss this further during our debrief.
Good morning, I'm here to report for duty on Flight 123. Can I please board the aircraft now?
I'm sorry, but we're currently conducting a security search on the aircraft. You won't be able to board just yet.
A security search? I've never been held up like this before. Can you give me an estimated time when I'll be able to board?

Okay, thank you. I've been here on time for my report, and I'm concerned about the delay. Can you please let me know what's going on and how long this will take?

Thank you. I'm going to board the aircraft now and get started on my pre-flight preparations.

(later, during the flight) Sir, I'll be happy to let you have a bathroom break, but could I request that another crew member stay nearby?

I understand your concerns. In hindsight, maybe we should have taken a more cautious approach. But we did receive reports of moderate turbulence, and I didn't think it would escalate to severe levels.

As flight attendants, our safety is compromised when we're not properly informed or prepared for turbulence. I also question the practice of requiring full beverage service on short flights like this one. It puts us at risk and diverts our attention from potential hazards.

I think it's essential that we have thorough pre-flight briefings, including information on turbulence and weather conditions. Hi, this is Flight 1212. I'm calling to report a concern regarding two passengers who boarded with dogs that weren't properly documented or restrained.
Good afternoon, Flight 1212. What's the situation?

During boarding, I observed a passenger in seat 8C with a pet in a carry-on kennel, which was okay, but the kennel was blocked by an IFE power box, so we had to swap seats. The bigger concern is a passenger in seat 25A who had a small dog under her coat. There was no documentation or indication on her manifest or special services list that she had an emotional support animal.
I see. Can you confirm if the passenger had a PNR updated with the dog as a service animal?

Not on my end. When I notified the gate agent about the undocumented ESA, I observed a customer service representative board the aircraft to inquire about the animal. But I didn't see any documentation or proper restraint for the dog.

Okay, I checked on it, and it looks like the passenger's PNR was updated after the flight to reflect the dog as a service animal, but it wasn't properly restrained, and there was no visible identification or control gear.

That's exactly my concern. As you know, that's a safety risk to passengers and crew. I'm filing a report to address this incident. I think we need to improve communication and compliance with documentation and restraint requirements to prevent similar incidents in the future.
I agree. I'll make sure to pass on the information to our team. Can you tell me more about the behavior of the dogs during the flight? Were they causing any disruptions?

The dog in the kennel was fine, didn't cause any issues. But the ESA in seat 25A... well, it was just not properly secured, and that's what worries me. I'm glad nothing happened, but it could have been a different story.
Understood. Thank you for bringing this to our attention, and I'll make sure to follow up on it. Appreciate your diligence in ensuring passenger and crew safety.
Hey, Karen, I'm still shaking my head about what happened on that flight. I'm glad we got him off the plane safely.
I know, I was getting really concerned when he boarded. He was struggling with his luggage and seemed disoriented. I thought for sure he was going to be a problem.

I couldn't agree more. A quick and simple screening process could help identify potential health risks before they board the aircraft. We'll review our procedures and see what we can do to improve.
